Title: Mac OS X Folder Permission Flaw May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in the enforcement of folder permissions.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
A local user can exploit a race condition in assignment of permissions on files in the system's cache folder and the Dashboard system widgets.  A local user may be able to write to files in those directories.

Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.

The vendor credits Michael Haller with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.1 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.1
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-006Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  89e432a13fc3de743b9444e2a33f3e989ceccdb4

Title: Apple LaunchServices Lets Remote Users Bypass the File Dowload Dialog
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple LaunchServices.  A remote user can create a file that will bypass download safety checks.
If a file extension and mime type is marked as unsafe but is not mapped to an Apple Uniform Type Identifier (UTI), then a query on certain forms of the file extension or mime type may not be properly marked as unsafe.  As a result, a remote user may be able to cause a malicious file to be downloaded without an appropriate safety check.

Mac OS X versions prior to 10.4 are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can create a file that will bypass download safety checks.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix as part of Security Update 2005-006, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.4.1 and Mac OS X Server v10.4.1
The download file is named:  "SecUpd2005-006Ti.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  89e432a13fc3de743b9444e2a33f3e989ceccdb4

Title: NetInfo Manager Incorrectly Displays the Status of the Root Account
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's NetInfo Manager.  The account status for the 'root' user account may be displayed incorrectly.
Apple reported that after the 'root' user logs in one time, then NetInfo Manager cannot be used to disable the account.  NetInfo Manager will also indicate (incorrectly) that  the account is disabled.  

Versions prior to Mac OS X 10.3 are not affected.
Impact': The account status for the 'root' user account may be display as 'disabled' when it is not actually disabled.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2004-09-30, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.3.5 and Mac OS X Server v10.3.5:

The download file is named: "SecUpd2004-09-30Pan.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  1660042cecdfca15866cc3a7be06c69ee52d68a3

Title: Apple AFP Server Bugs Let Local Users Terminate Mount Sessions and Remote Users Read Drop Box Items
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in Apple's AFP Server.  A local user can cause denial of service conditions.  A remote user may be able to read files in a write-only Drop Box.
Apple reported that a local user with guest privileges can mount an Apple File Protocol (AFP) volume and modify SessionDestroy packets to cause user mounts on the target system to terminate [CVE: CVE-2004-0921].

It is also reported that a remote user can mount an AFP volume an obtain read-write privileges on a write-only AFP Drop Box.  This is due to an incorrect setting of the guest group id (gid) [CVE: CVE-2004-0922].

Versions prior to 10.3 are not affected by either of these vulnerabilities.
Impact':
A local user can cause AFP mount sessions to terminate.

A remote user may be able to read files in a write-only Drop Box.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2004-09-30, available from the Software Update pane in System Preferences, or Apple's Software Downloads web site at:

http://www.apple.com/support/downloads/

For Mac OS X v10.3.5 and Mac OS X Server v10.3.5:

The download file is named: "SecUpd2004-09-30Pan.dmg"
Its SHA-1 digest is:  1660042cecdfca15866cc3a7be06c69ee52d68a3

Title: Mac OS X CoreFoundation Buffer Overflow and Library Loading Bugs Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in Apple Mac OS X in CoreFoundation.  A local user can execute arbitrary code.
Apple reported that a local user can cause an application using CoreFoundation CFPlugIn facilities to load an arbitrary user-supplied library [CVE: CVE-2004-0821] with the privileges of the application.  A local user can gain elevated privileges.

The vendor credits Kikuchi Masashi with reporting this flaw.

It is also reported that a local user can modify a certain environment variable to trigger a buffer overflow in CoreFoundation [CVE: CVE-2004-0822] and execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges.

The vendor credits aaron@vtty.com with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with elevated privileges.

Title: Apple Mac OS X LaunchServices Component May Let Remote Users Register and Execute Applications
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's Mac OS X in LaunchServices.  A remote user may be able to cause the target user to run certain applications.
Apple reported that a remote user may be able to cause LaunchServices to register an application and subsequently cause the application to run.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause an application to run on the target user's system.
Solution:

Title: Mac OS X Bug in Apple File Protocol (AFP) Over SSH May Fail to Encrypt Some Connectoins
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Apple File Protocol (AFP) implementation on Mac OS X.  When running AFP connections over SSH, some connections may not be encrypted.
It is reported that in some cases, AFP sessions will be established in the clear even though both the client and server have secure connections enabled.
Impact': A remote user monitoring the connection between the client and the server can view unencrypted connections.
Solution: According to a report by Chris Adams (improbable.org), version 10.3.2 is not affected.

Title: Mac OS X TruBlueEnvironment Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow was reported in the Mac OS X TruBlueEnvironment (Classic Emulator).  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
In January 2004, @stake reported that a local user can set a specially crafted environment variable to trigger a stack overflow in TruBlueEnvironment and execute arbitrary code.  The TruBlueEnvironment is reportedly configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, so the code will run with root privileges.

The original advisory is available at:

Title: (Apple Issues Fix) Mac OS X 'cd9660.util' Buffer Overflow Yields Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Mac OS X in the 'cd9660.util' ISO 9660 file system utility.  A local user can gain root privileges on the target system.
It is reported that a local user can supply a specially crafted command line argument to the '/System/Library/Filesystems/cd9660.fs/cd9660.util' utility to trigger a buffer overflow.  Because the utility is reportedly configured with set user id (setuid) root user privileges, any arbitrary code that may be executed will run with root privileges.

A demonstration exploit command is provided:

./cd9660.util -p `perl -e "print 'A'x512"`
Impact': A local user can gain root privileges.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix for Panther and Jaguar.

CodeSamurai reported that a physically local user with access to the keyboard can cause keystrokes to be passed to the operating system.  A physically local user can send keystrokes during a short period of time between when the screen effect is active and the authentication window is displayed, the report said.
Impact': A physically local user can generate keystrokes that will bypass the screen saver keyboard lock and take actions on the desktop.

Title: (Apple Issues Fix for OS X 10.2) Service Location Protocol Daemon (slpd) Temporary File Flaw May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Version(s): Mac OS X 10.2 and prior versions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X Service Location Protocol responder (slpd).  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges on the system.
It is reported that when Personal File Sharing is enabled on Mac OS X, a local user can exploit a temporary file vulnerability. A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from a critical file on the system to a file that slpd will create in the '/tmp' directory.  Then, when slpd creates the temporary file, the symlinked file will be written to with root level privileges.  A local user may be able to cause slpd to modify a file to grant the user root level access on the system.

The report notes that Personal File Sharing is turned off by default.

The vendor credits @stake with reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user may be able to modify files with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution:
Apple has released a fix as part of Security Update 2003-11-19 for Mac OS X 10.2.8, available at:

  * Software Update pane in System Preferences

  * Apple's Software Downloads web site:

Title: Mac OS X Kernel Can Be Crashed By Local Users Sending a Long Command Line Argument
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X operating system.  A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
@stake reported that a local user can supply a long command line argument to trigger the flaw.  In addition to causing a kernel crash, it is reported that a local user may be able to view small portions of kernel memory.

According to the report, the overflow will not be logged.

The report indicates that it may be possible in some cases for this vulnerability to be exploited by a remote user if a network-based application spawns a process using user-supplied input.
Impact': A local user can cause the kernel to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version of Mac OS X (10.3).  For more information, see:

http://www.apple.com/macosx/

CodeSamurai reported that a physically local user with access to the keyboard can cause keystrokes to be passed to the operating system.  A physically local user can send keystrokes during a short period of time between when the screen effect is active and the authentication window is displayed, the report said.
Impact': A physically local user can generate keystrokes that will bypass the screen saver keyboard lock and take actions on the desktop.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mac OS X Discloses Core Files to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X kernel.  A local user may be able to overwrite arbitrary files and read root-owned core files in certain configurations.
@stake reported that if the target system is running with core files enabled (which is not the default configuration), a local user can invoke a symlink attack.  A local user can create a symbolic link from a critical file on the system to a predictable core file name (of the form 'core.[processid]') in the '/cores' directory.  Then, when the target process dumps core, the symlinked file will be overwritten.  The local user can thus read the contents of the core file.
Impact': A local user can overwrite arbitrary files with root privileges.  A local user can view core files.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly issued a fixed version of Mac OS X (10.3).  Users that cannot upgrade can make sure that core file creation is disabled (which is reportedly the default configuration).

Title: Mac OS X Default Directory Copy Permissions May Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact': A local user may be able to replace an application binary with a modified binary to gain elevated privileges when a target user attempts to execute the application.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version of Mac OS X (10.3).  In the fixed version, Finder will reportedly preserve the permissions on copied folders.

For more information, visit:

http://www.apple.com/macosx/

It is reported that a remote user may be able to access an account created by Workgroup Manager between the time the account is created and the time the account is saved.

Title: Mac OS X IPSec Policy Flaw May Remote Users Bypass Access Controls
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X IPSec implementation.  A remote user may be able to send packets that bypass the IPSec access controls.
Apple reported that Mac OS X does not properly handle certain incoming security policies that match by port.  Some incoming traffic that is not explicitly allowed by the IPSec security policies may be accepted by the target system.  No further details were provided.
Impact': A remote user may be able to send unauthorized traffic to or through the target server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (10.2.6), available via:

    * The Software Update pane in System Preferences
    * Apple Software Downloads (http://www.apple.com/swupdates/)

Title: Mac OS X File Sharing/Service Gives Authenticated Users Read Access to the Write-Only DropBox
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X File Sharing and File Service.  An authenticated user can gain access to the "DropBox".
Apple reports that an authenticated user can change the permissions of the "DropBox" folder, which is ordinarily a write-only folder. This allows a guest user to gain access to the contents of the folder.

This vulnerability affects Personal File Sharing on Mac OS X and Apple File Service on Mac OS X Server when the service is enabled.
Impact': An authenticated user (including a guest user) can read the contents of the DropBox folder.

Title: Mac OS X DirectoryService Unsafe System() Call Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X DirectoryService.  A local user can gain root access on the system.  A remote user can cause the DirectoryService to crash.
@stake, Inc. reported that that DirectoryService uses a system() call to execute the touch(1) command upon startup but fails to specify the full path of the touch command.  A local user can reportedly modify the PATH environment variable to point to an alternate touch(1) binary containing the local user's arbitrary code.  The report indicates that /usr/sbin/DirectoryService is configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges and runs by default.  The code will then be executed with root privileges.

It is also reported that a remote user can cause the service to crash by connecting to port 625 repeatedly.

[Editor's note:  @stake does not permit us to post their advisory.  It is available at http://www.atstake.com/research/advisories/2003/a041003-1.txt]
Impact': A remote user can cause the service to crash.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.

Title: MacOS Classic Emulator TruBlueEnvironment Access Control Bug Lets Local Users Create Files With Root Privileges to Gain Root Level Access
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's TruBlueEnvironment component of the MacOS Classic Emulator.  A local user can obtain root privileges.
@stake reported that a local user can set a certain environment variable to create or overwrite arbitrary files on the system with root privileges and the local user's umask file creation permissions.  The environment variable is used to specify the file location to write debugging information.

If the specified file exists, TruBlueEnvironment will overwrite the file with null contents (zero bytes).  Otherwise, the file will be created.

A local user can, for example, create world writeable files that may be later executed with root privileges via the cron utility.
Impact': A local user can create or overwrite files with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version of the Mac OS X operating system (10.2.4).  The Mac OS X 10.2.4 client Software Update may be obtained from:

* Software Update pane in System Preferences

- OR -

* Apple's Software Downloads web site:

Title: (Apple Issues Fix) Re: Mac OS X SoftwareUpdate Feature Uses Unauthenticated Connections for Downloading and Automatically Installing Software Updates, Allowing Remote Users to Install Arbitrary Code on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X operating system 'SoftwareUpdate' feature.  A remote user could, in certain situations, cause arbitrary code to be installed on the system with root privileges.
It is reported that the default configuration of the 'SoftwareUpdate' feature will run weekly.  The feature apparently uses HTTP with no authentication, allowing a remote user to cause arbitrary code to be downloaded and automatically installed by a target host when the target host performs 'SoftwareUpdate'.  To do this, the remote user must control the local domain name system (DNS), spoof the DNS, or poison the host's ARP cache.  Several utilities are available to assist in these tasks.

According to the report, SoftwareUpdate connects via HTTP to swscan.apple.com and issues a "GET" request for /scanningpoints/ scanningpointX.xml.  The server returns a list of software and current versions for the requesting host to check.  Next, the requesting host sends a list of currently installed software to /WebObjects/SoftwareUpdatesServer at swquery.apple.com via an HTTP POST command. If any new software is available from Apple, the SoftwareUpdatesServer reportedly responds with the location of the software, size, and a brief description. If no new software is available, the server sends a blank page with the comment "No Updates".

Some demonstration exploit code and instructions are available at:

http://www.cunap.com/~hardingr/projects/osx/exploit.html
Impact': A remote user with control of the local domain name system (DNS) or with the ability to spoof DNS or ARP protocol entries can cause a target user to download an install arbitrary code with root privileges when the target user (or the target user's host) runs the 'SoftwareUpdate' feature.  This can give the remote user full control over the operating system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix.  Packages presented via the Software Update mechanism are reportedly cryptographically signed and the new Software Update client (1.4.6) checks for a valid signature before installing new packages.

Software updates are available via:

- The Software Update pane in System Preferences 
- Apple's Software Downloads web page:  

  http://www.info.apple.com/support/downloads.html

Title: MacOS DNS Bug Lets Remote DNS Servers Crash the Operating System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): OS 9 (confirmed in 9.0.4 and 9.2.2), OS X in 'Classic' mode
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the MacOS operating system.  A remote DNS server can cause the system to crash in certain situations.
It is reported that the MacOS does not properly handle certain potentially invalid DNS messages returned by DNS servers in response to an IP address lookup.

It is reported that a local user can perform a reverse DNS lookup on certain IP addresses (such as 206.207.151.40) to cause the system to crash.  If the Macintosh is acting as a server and if DNS lookups are enabled on the server, then a remote user can cause the server to crash by using the IP address of a site whose DNS server will return invalid packets.

It is reported that the vendor has been notified (bug #2844306).
Impact': A local user can cause the system to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash in a certain configuration.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Mac OS X PPP Utility Discloses PPP Configuration Username and Password to Local Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Apple's ppp utility for Mac OS X.  A local user can view the ppp username and password.
It is reported that the ppp user name and password entered in `Internet Connect' are visible as command line arguments to pppd.

A demonstration exploit is provided:

ps -axwwww -o pid,command|grep pppd|grep -v grep
Impact': A local user can view the ppp username and password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Apple Issues Fix) Re: Mac OS X NetInfo Manager Lets Local Users Log in as Root Level Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Mac OS X NetInfo Manager that lets local users obtain root level access to the system.
It is reported that the NetInfo Manager can be used by non-root users to obtain root level access using set user id (suid) root applications.

A demonstration exploit example is provided:

- Open up the terminal application (Terminal.app)
- Quit the terminal application
- Open up NetInfo Manager and leave it in the foreground
- Open up the Terminal application from the "Recent Items" list in the Apple Menu.

This should give the local user a terminal session logged in as root.
Impact': A local user can obtain root level access on the system.
Solution:
Apple has issued a fix ("Mac OS X v10.1 Security Update 10-19-01").

Software updates are available via the Software Update pane in System Preferences or via Apple's Software Downloads web page:

http://www.info.apple.com/support/downloads.html

Title: Mac OS X Desktop Folder Security Permission Fix Fails on Certain 10.0.x to 10.1 Upgrades
Version(s): upgrade from 10.0.x to 10.1 for French, German, Italian, and Spanish versions.  English version is not affected.
Description:
It was reported that the Mac OS X 10.0.x to 10.1 upgrades fail to fix the previously reported Destop Folder security permission flaw. This affects only certain Mac OS X language versions.  Local users can view and modify the desktop of other users.
The previously reported vulnerability noted that verion 10.0.x used improper drwxrwxrwx permissions for the Desktop folder (i.e., global read, write, and execute).

It is reported that the French, German, Italian, and Spanish upgrades are vulnerable.  While 10.1 is reported to fix the flaw, the above mentioned upgrades require a 10.0.x configuration for the upgrade to function.  If a '/Users/<login>/Desktop' directory is vulnerable on a 10.0.x configuration, it will still remain vulnerable after the 10.1 update.  Only new users that are created after 10.1 update will have secure permissions on their '/Users/<login>/Desktop' folder.
Impact': A local user can view and modify the contents of another user's Desktop folder.  In particular, the 'admin' Desktop folder is vulnerable.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests manually changing the permissions of at least the 'admin' Desktop folder.

Title: (Additional Exploit Information) Re: Mac OS X Discloses Directory Contents to Remote Users When Running a Web Server
Description:
A file permission vulnerability was reported in Apple's Mac OS X operating system.  The 'Finder' feature reportedly creates hidden but world-readable directory summary files that can be accessed by remote users if the host is running a web server, such as Apache.
It is reported that an additional database file (.FBCIndex) may disclose directory information to remote users.  The file is apparently world readable.

In the original report (see the Message History), it was reported that the hidden file ".DS_Store" could disclose directory listings to remote users if a web server is operating on the host.
Impact': A remote user can obtain directory listings from Mac OS X if the target host is running a web server and if the Finder has been used on the target host to view the web directory.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, access controls can be used in the web server.  For example, with Apache web server, the following directive was reported as a solution:

The solution is, again, to use a <FilesMatch> directive in httpd.conf to
forbid retrieval of this file:

# The Finder creates an invisible .DS_Store file in each directory.
# For 'no-index' access controls to be effective, we had better forbid
# retrieval of that file as well. Note that we have to protect
# against the same case-insensitivity bug as above.
#
<FilesMatch "^\.[Dd][Ss]_[Ss]">
Order allow,deny
Deny from all
</FilesMatch>

Title: Mac OS X Discloses Directory Contents to Remote Users When Running a Web Server
Description:
A file permission vulnerability was reported in Apple's Mac OS X operating system.  The 'Finder' feature reportedly creates hidden but world-readable directory summary files that can be accessed by remote users if the host is running a web server, such as Apache.
It is reported that the Finder creates an invisible file named ".DS_Store" in each directory.  The file apparently includes a list of files in the directory.  If the host is running a web server, a remote user can use the following type of URL to retrieve the file and obtain the list of files in the directory, even if web server indexing is blocked:

http://[targethost]/some_directory/.dS_store

The file is given world-readable permissions.
Impact': A remote user can obtain directory listings from Mac OS X if the target host is running a web server and if the Finder has been used on the target host to view the web directory.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, access controls can be used in the web server.  For example, with Apache web server, the following directive was reported as a solution:

The solution is, again, to use a <FilesMatch> directive in httpd.conf to
forbid retrieval of this file:

# The Finder creates an invisible .DS_Store file in each directory.
# For 'no-index' access controls to be effective, we had better forbid
# retrieval of that file as well. Note that we have to protect
# against the same case-insensitivity bug as above.
#
<FilesMatch "^\.[Dd][Ss]_[Ss]">
Order allow,deny
Deny from all
</FilesMatch>

Title: Macintosh Open Firmware Passwords Can Be Disclosed to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Apple's Open Firmware implementation that allows a local user to obtain the system boot password (if one is used).
Apple reportedly introduced the system boot password in FirmWare Update 4.17.  This protection method is reportedly similar to the BIOS password protection found on Intel computers.

mSec has discovered that the password can be retrieved by a local user that has access to the operating system after the system has been booted.  mSec has released a tool 'FWSucker' that demonstrates the vulnerability, available at:

http://www.msec.net/software/index.html#fwsucker
Impact': A local user with access to the operating system after the system has been booted can obtain the firmware password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (A User Provides More Information) Re: Mac OS X Default Installation Lets Local Users Read and Make Changes to Another User's Desktop Folder
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Apple's Mac OS X operating system that, in the default configuration, lets local users access the Desktop folders of other users with read and write privileges.  [Editor's Note:  Several users have reported that they were unable to reproduce the vulnerability.]
It is reported that the permissions of the directory /Users/yourname/Desktop (which reportedly shows the desktop) are set to: xrwxrwxrwx, allowing every local user to view and make changes to other users' Desktop folders. 

The vendor has reportedly been informed.

A user provides some additional information (see Source Message), indicating that the improper permissions may have been set by a beta version, but that the non-beta full release version does not seem to have the problem.
Impact': A local user can view and modify items on another user's desktop.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report provides a fix:

chmod 755 or chmod 750 /Users/yourname/Desktop

Title: Mac OS Runtime for Java Permits Unauthorized Applets to Access the System Clipboard
Description:
Apple reports that versions of Mac OS Runtime for Java (MRJ) contain a vulnerability that may disclose user information to remote users.
The vulnerability permits unauthorized Java applets to access to the system clipboard.

The nature of the vulnerability was not reported by the vendor.
Impact': A remote user could, via a Java applet, obtain information from the system clipboard.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (2.2.5).  See the Vendor URL for the fixed version.
